option.name: title_text
option.value: Regular Substantive Interaction (RSI): Why does it matter:

string_table.name: pxabnsnfns10111110101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: In your opinion, what is the most significant consequence associated with the lack of Regular Substantive Interaction (RSI) in online courses? Rank the following choices from greatest to least consequence. Then click Submit to continue with the course.
LMS Tools: Discussions and Video Assignments
Which tools do you currently use in your course? Select all that apply. Click Submit to continue when you are done.
Match the definitions to the correct RSI term.
Discussions and video assignments need the following characteristics to reflect regular and substantive interaction (select all that apply):
Select the characteristics of gradable rubrics that make them ideal for RSI (select all that apply):

Title IV financial aid program participation is restricted for institutions offering over ##% of their courses through correspondence or enrolling more than ##% of their students in correspondence courses.
Correspondence courses comply with Title IV funding requirements.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Blue Mountain Community College. (n.d.) Regular and Substantive Interaction (RSI) Examples.
Cancilla, D. (2018). Regular and Substantive Interactions: The Accreditation Dance of Online Courses. University of Missouri, Kansas City.
Downs, Lindsey. (2022, November 8). “What is ‘Regular and Substantive Interaction?” WCET.
Empire State University. (2023). Background: Definitions of Distance Education and Correspondence Courses.
NC-SARA. (2020, October 10). U.S. Department of Education Issues Final Rules on Distance Education and Innovation.
Office of Postsecondary Education, Department of Education. (2020, September 02). Distance Education and Innovation Final Rule.
Online Learning Consortium. (n.d.) Regular & Substantive Interaction.
U.S. Department of Education. (2020, September 2). Negotiated Rulemaking for Higher Education 2018-19

terms.term: Course-related updates and important information shared by instructors with the students. For purposes of RSI, course announcments should include relevant feedback on class performance as well as brief opportunities for supplemental instruction.
Interaction that occurs at different times, allowing students to participate in discussions, forums, and assignments at their convenience.

A correspondence course is a form of distance education where instructional materials are exchanged by mail or electronic means, with limited or no direct interaction with an instructor. Correspondence courses do not comply with Title IV funding.
A section of the course that provides the overview of the course structure, requirements, schedule, expectations, and communication methods.
An outline of the course's content, objectives, expectations, and assessment methods provided to students at the beginning of the course.

Educational instruction delivered synchronously or asynchronously to students who are separated from the instructor by using one or more types of communicative technology in a way that supports regular and substantive interaction.
Activities designed to provide feedback and measure students' progress throughout the course.

The accredited subject-matter expert who is responsible for conveying knowledge and mentoring the success of each student. Additionally, the instructor must be an accredited subject-matter expert who is responsible for conveying knowledge and mentoring the success of each student. As of July 1, 2021, there is an explicit requirement that the instructor should have approval from the institutions accrediting body in order to teach. [U.S. Dept. of Education, 34 CFR 600.2, Part Three]

Specific, planned contact between the learner and the instructor to foster learning of the course subject matter, such as ive video lectures, online discussions, feedback on assignments, and email exchanges. To meet RSI standards, interactions in a course must take place in a minimum of 2 of the following modes: Providing direct instruction; assessing or providng feedback on a student's coursework; providing information or responding to questions about the content of a course or competency; facilitating a group discussion regarding the content of a course or competency; Other instructional activities approved by the institution’s or program’s accrediting agency. [Empire State University, 2023].
Designated times that an instructor is available to meet with students for one-on-one discussion and support.

A virtual space, especially within an LMS, in which students can connect in academic discussions and share their unique viewpoints with their peers and instructor. For purposes of RSI, online discussions allow instructors to provide genuine, personal responses, spot confusion or misinterpretation of the academic material, and quickly provide supplemental instruction or to go deeper into a topic of interest.
Scheduled interactions that occur consistently, frequently, and predictably, that are relevant to the course, and includes proactive tracking with the purpose of supporting student success.
A requirement by the U.S. Department of Education for distance education courses to ensure active engagement and meaningful interaction between students and instructors.

A set of guidelines or criteria used to evaluate and provide feedback on student assignments and activities, usually presented in a hierarchichal table. Digital rubrics support RSI by providing clear expectations before the student attempts the assignment, streamlining the grading process afterward, and allowing for personalized feedback to individual students.

The meaningful and academic nature of the interactions between students and instructors that go beyond surface-level exchanges and involve discussions, feedback, and other activities that contribute to the students' learning and understanding of the course material.
Final assessments used to measure students' overall learning and achievement at the end of the course.
Real-time interaction between students and instructors, such as live video lectures, chats, or webinars.

Federal financial aid programs that provide financial assistance, such as grants, loans, and work-study opportunities, to eligible students pursuing higher education at accredited institutions. Title IV funds are tied to the quality of course interaction as measured for regular and substantive interaction. Institutions that offer over 50% of their courses via correspondence or enroll more than 50% of their students in correspondence courses do not qualify for Title IV funds.
